articles.headline: 6 Strategies to Extend Savings Without Working Longer
articles.snippet: Working into your mid-60s isn’t always an option, but planning ahead to maximize Social Security, reducing taxes and using a reverse mortgage can help stretch savings.
articles.abstract: Working into your mid-60s isn’t always an option, but planning ahead to maximize Social Security, reducing taxes and using a reverse mortgage can help stretch savings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Karen Arndt, 60, has tinkered with several retirement calculators, and they all generate the same finger-wagging advice: Keep working, they seem to warn. You’re not even close.

articles.headline: Court Forbids F.D.A. From Blocking Truthful Promotion of Drug
articles.snippet: The decision clears the way for Amarin to promote patient use of its drug Vascepa in a way that the F.D.A. declined to approve.
articles.abstract: The decision clears the way for Amarin to promote patient use of its drug Vascepa in a way that the F.D.A. declined to approve.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge said on Friday that the Food and Drug Administration could not prohibit the truthful promotion of a drug for unapproved uses because doing so would violate the protection of free speech.

articles.headline: A Once-Flourishing Pima Cotton Industry Withers in an Arid California
articles.snippet: The crop, used in high-end clothing, has been hit hard by the drought, and farmers and officials are struggling to preserve the industry and the environment.
articles.abstract: The crop, used in high-end clothing, has been hit hard by the drought, and farmers and officials are struggling to preserve the industry and the environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — Up and down the San Joaquin Valley, vast fields that once grew cotton lie fallow, remnants of a boom and bust fueled by a worldwide demand for premium T-shirts and linens.

articles.headline: Life Sentence for James Holmes, Aurora Theater Gunman
articles.snippet: The jury rejected the death penalty for the man who carried out a 2012 shooting rampage in a Colorado movie theater.
articles.abstract: The jury rejected the death penalty for the man who carried out a 2012 shooting rampage in a Colorado movie theater.
articles.lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — In a decision that surprised many in this community, a jury sentenced James E. Holmes on Friday to life in prison with no chance of parole, rejecting the death penalty for the man who carried out a 2012 shooting rampage that killed 12 people in a Colorado movie theater.

articles.headline: Bringing Paternity Leave Into the Mainstream
articles.snippet: Paid paternity leave offers broad benefits, but it won’t become common until prominent men use it and don’t pay a penalty for doing so.
articles.abstract: Paid paternity leave offers broad benefits, but it won’t become common until prominent men use it and don’t pay a penalty for doing so.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, two companies joined in an unfolding race to provide ever more generous paid parental leave. Netflix said it planned to offer unlimited leave in the first year after a child’s arrival to many (though not all) of its employees, while Microsoft said it would substantially increase the paid leave that it will provide.

articles.headline: Fears of Lasting Rift as Obama Battles Pro-Israel Group on Iran
articles.snippet: The president accused the American Israel Public Affairs Committee of spending millions on advertising to try to defeat the accord, as well as spreading misinformation about it.
articles.abstract: The president accused the American Israel Public Affairs Committee of spending millions on advertising to try to defeat the accord, as well as spreading misinformation about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama had a tough message for the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac, the powerful pro-Israel group that is furiously campaigning against the Iran nuclear accord, when he met with two of its leaders at the White House this week. The president accused Aipac of spending millions of dollars in advertising against the deal and spreading false claims about it, people in the meeting recalled.

articles.headline: Fear That Debate Could Hurt G.O.P. in Women’s Eyes
articles.snippet: Several candidates took hard-line stances on abortion, and Donald Trump refused to renounce his past descriptions of women as “fat pigs.”
articles.abstract: Several candidates took hard-line stances on abortion, and Donald Trump refused to renounce his past descriptions of women as “fat pigs.”
articles.lead_paragraph: After Senator Marco Rubio of Florida insisted at the Republican presidential debate that rape and incest victims should carry pregnancies to term, aides to Hillary Rodham Clinton could barely contain their delight at his unyielding stance, rushing to tell reporters at her headquarters that those remarks would hurt Mr. Rubio with female voters.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Hand-Wringing in G.O.P. After Donald Trump’s Remarks on Megyn Kelly
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s suggestion that Ms. Kelly had questioned him forcefully at the Republican debate because she was menstruating cost him a speaking slot at an influential gathering.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s suggestion that Ms. Kelly had questioned him forcefully at the Republican debate because she was menstruating cost him a speaking slot at an influential gathering.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s suggestion that a Fox News journalist had questioned him forcefully at the Republican presidential debate because she was menstruating cost him a speaking slot Saturday night at an influential gathering of conservatives in Atlanta. It also raised new questions about how much longer Republican Party leaders would have to contend with Mr. Trump’s disruptive presence in the primary field.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: A Year After Ferguson, Housing Segregation Defies Tools to Erase It
articles.snippet: A year after the fatal shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., interviews with residents, activists and academics suggest that forces perpetuating housing segregation remain present.
articles.abstract: A year after the fatal shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., interviews with residents, activists and academics suggest that forces perpetuating housing segregation remain present.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — When she tore open the manila envelope on a sweltering morning in early June, Crystal Wade thought she had unlocked her ticket to freedom.

articles.headline: Pain of Puerto Rico’s Debt Crisis Is Weighing on the Little Guy, Too
articles.snippet: The plunging value of government bonds has hurt tens of thousands of Puerto Ricans, and a restructuring of the debt could heap more hardship on them.
articles.abstract: The plunging value of government bonds has hurt tens of thousands of Puerto Ricans, and a restructuring of the debt could heap more hardship on them.
articles.lead_paragraph: To Lev Steinberg, it seemed like a good place to park his nest egg.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Emails Take Long Path to Controversy
articles.snippet: The former secretary of state’s email account has become a significant early chapter in her run for the presidency and a new element of her evolving portrait.
articles.abstract: The former secretary of state’s email account has become a significant early chapter in her run for the presidency and a new element of her evolving portrait.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Earlier this summer, the inspector general of the nation’s intelligence agencies contacted the longtime lawyer for Hillary and Bill Clinton with a pointed question. Classified information had been found in a small sample of 30,000 messages from the former secretary of state’s private email account. The inspector general, I. Charles McCullough III, wanted to know from the lawyer, David E. Kendall, where copies of the message collection might still be stored.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: On the Defensive, the S.E.C. Quietly Pursues High-Profile Cases
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission continues to adapt its regulatory role, pushing ahead with insider trading cases and one involving cybersecurity.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission continues to adapt its regulatory role, pushing ahead with insider trading cases and one involving cybersecurity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s chief regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission, appears to some to be in need of a makeover.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: A Moscow of Dancing Feet, Under an Iron Fist
articles.snippet: The Russian capital is looking ever more like an elegant European capital, but its political life is marching steadily in the opposite direction.
articles.abstract: The Russian capital is looking ever more like an elegant European capital, but its political life is marching steadily in the opposite direction.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s capital city has worn many outfits since the fall of the Soviet Union.

articles.headline: Similarities Aside, Bernie Sanders Isn’t Rerunning Howard Dean’s 2004 Race
articles.snippet: Both Democrats from Vermont caught a populist wave, but there are crucial differences between the men and between their eras.
articles.abstract: Both Democrats from Vermont caught a populist wave, but there are crucial differences between the men and between their eras.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — It was a summer Friday night in Iowa, and a high school auditorium here was overflowing, as more than 1,000 people, holding signs and collecting names, spilled out into the lobby and onto the sidewalk. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont strolled onstage — tieless, his white hair askew, his shoulders stooped — and stopped at the sight in front of him.

articles.headline: Teacher Shortages Spur a Nationwide Hiring Scramble (Credentials Optional)
articles.snippet: Just a few years after the recession caused widespread layoffs for teachers, school districts now find themselves with numerous job vacancies and few qualified candidates to choose from.
articles.abstract: Just a few years after the recession caused widespread layoffs for teachers, school districts now find themselves with numerous job vacancies and few qualified candidates to choose from.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROHNERT PARK, Calif. — In a stark about-face from just a few years ago, school districts have gone from handing out pink slips to scrambling to hire teachers.

articles.headline: After Nokia Layoffs, Tech Workers in Finland Regroup and Refocus
articles.snippet: Thousands of laid-off workers have started their own businesses or have been recruited by other tech companies lured to Finland by its surplus of talent.
articles.abstract: Thousands of laid-off workers have started their own businesses or have been recruited by other tech companies lured to Finland by its surplus of talent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kimmo Kalliola knows the feeling that thousands of Finns have been dealing with over the last couple of years. He spent more than a decade working on geolocation positioning at Nokia, a highly technical job, but the Finnish tech giant hit hard times. In late 2012, Mr. Kalliola and 10,000 others at the company were laid off.

articles.headline: Mtime Helps Hollywood Clear China’s Marketing Hurdles and Reach Fans
articles.snippet: Trailers and TV ads are tough marketing tools to use in China, but the service Mtime offers packages to help American filmmakers reach a huge, and quickly growing, audience.
articles.abstract: Trailers and TV ads are tough marketing tools to use in China, but the service Mtime offers packages to help American filmmakers reach a huge, and quickly growing, audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Now that Hollywood has mostly figured out how to get its biggest movies approved for release in China, studio marketers here are grappling with a new puzzle: What is the best way to woo China’s ticket buyers?
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Amy Qin

articles.headline: Investors Find Ways to Indirectly Profit From Valuable Start-Ups
articles.snippet: Companies without deep pockets and connections are coming up with roundabout ways to get a piece of the action.
articles.abstract: Companies without deep pockets and connections are coming up with roundabout ways to get a piece of the action.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb’s valuation has ballooned over the last few years as large financial firms like Fidelity Investments and T. Rowe Price have rushed to invest in the start-up. But a small San Francisco-based hedge fund called Pier 88 Investment Partners has decided that the fervor for Airbnb shares creates a different kind of opportunity.

articles.headline: Inside Syria: Kurds Roll Back ISIS, but Alliances Are Strained
articles.snippet: Even as Kurds are assisting in the campaign against the Islamic State in Syria, Turkey, a latecomer to the U.S.-led mission, is also bombarding Kurdish insurgent positions.
articles.abstract: Even as Kurds are assisting in the campaign against the Islamic State in Syria, Turkey, a latecomer to the U.S.-led mission, is also bombarding Kurdish insurgent positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: HASAKA, Syria — Green drapes were drawn against the sun, cloaking the room where members of a Syrian Kurdish militia huddled around walkie-talkies, assiduously taking down GPS coordinates.

articles.headline: Emergency Declared in Ferguson After Shooting
articles.snippet: Charges were filed against an 18-year-old who was shot by the police on the anniversary of the killing of Michael Brown, and late Monday police arrested more protesters after isolated scuffles.
articles.abstract: Charges were filed against an 18-year-old who was shot by the police on the anniversary of the killing of Michael Brown, and late Monday police arrested more protesters after isolated scuffles.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The St. Louis County executive declared a state of emergency here on Monday as officials and activists sought to regain control of the volatile streets after plainclothes police officers shot and critically wounded an 18-year-old black man who they said was firing on them late the night before.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway to Buy Aerospace Supplier for $37.2 Billion
articles.snippet: The transaction for Precision Castparts is the latest major deal for Mr. Buffett’s company as it has looked to strike a big takeover.
articles.abstract: The transaction for Precision Castparts is the latest major deal for Mr. Buffett’s company as it has looked to strike a big takeover.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a lieutenant to Warren E. Buffett first invested in Precision Castparts three years ago, the billionaire had hardly heard of the metal parts manufacturer.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Chad Bray
